quiz.title: Physics 12: Unit 5 Quiz 2
quiz.subtitle: Circular Motion Dynamics: Tension in Horizontal & Vertical Circles
quiz.subject: Physics 12
quiz.topic: Forces in Uniform Circular Motion, Tension in Strings

questions.question: A 0.500 kg ball is tied to a 1.20 m string and whirled in a horizontal circle at a constant speed of 6.00 m/s. What is the tension in the string?
questions.explanation: Tension provides the centripetal force. T = m v² / r = (0.500 kg × (6.00 m/s)²) / 1.20 m = 15.0 N.

questions.question: A 2.00 kg bucket is swung in a vertical circle of radius 1.00 m. What is the minimum speed at the top so the water doesn't spill? (Use g=10.0 m/s²)
questions.explanation: At the minimum speed, gravity alone provides the centripetal force: mg = mv²/r. Thus, v_min = √(g r) = √(10.0 × 1.00) = 3.16 m/s.

questions.question: A 2.00 kg bucket is swung in a vertical circle of radius 1.00 m with a speed of 7.00 m/s at the bottom. What is the tension? (Use g=10.0 m/s²)
questions.explanation: At the bottom, the net upward force is the centripetal force: T - mg = m v²/r. Therefore, T = m(g + v²/r) = 2.00 kg × (10.0 + 49.0) = 118 N.

questions.question: A 0.200 kg ball on a 0.800 m string is swung in a vertical circle. The tension at the top of the circle is measured to be 1.00 N. What is the ball's speed at the top? (Use g=9.80 m/s²)
questions.explanation: At the top, both tension and gravity point toward the center: T + mg = m v²/r. Solving for speed: v = √[ r (T/m + g) ] = √[ 0.800 m × (1.00 N / 0.200 kg + 9.80 m/s²) ] = √[ 0.800 × (5.00 + 9.80) ] = √[ 0.800 × 14.80 ] = √11.84 = 3.44 m/s.

questions.question: A conical pendulum has a 0.100 kg mass on a 1.00 m string at a 30° angle. What is the tension? (Use g=10.0 m/s², cos30°=0.8660)
questions.explanation: Vertical equilibrium: T cosθ = mg → T = mg / cosθ = (0.100 × 10.0) / 0.8660 = 1.00 / 0.8660 = 1.1547 N ≈ 1.15 N.

questions.question: A 0.100 kg conical pendulum on a 1.00 m string at 30° angle has what speed? (Use g=10.0 m/s², sin30°=0.5)
questions.explanation: Radius r = L sinθ = 1.00 × 0.5 = 0.500 m. From vertical equilibrium, T = mg/cosθ = 1.1547 N. Horizontal force provides centripetal force: T sinθ = m v²/r → v = √(T sinθ × r / m) = √(1.1547 × 0.5 × 0.500 / 0.100) = √2.88675 = 1.699 m/s ≈ 1.69 m/s.

questions.question: A 1500 kg car travels over a hill with a circular crest of radius 70.0 m at 25.0 m/s. What is the normal force from the road at the crest? (Use g=9.80 m/s²)
questions.explanation: At the crest, the net downward force is the centripetal force: mg - N = m v²/r. Therefore, N = m(g - v²/r) = 1500 kg × (9.80 - (25.0)²/70.0) = 1500 × (9.80 - 8.9286) = 1307 N ≈ 1.31 × 10³ N.

questions.question: A 0.500 kg ball is whirled in a horizontal circle on a 1.50 m string. If the string can withstand a maximum tension of 50.0 N, what is the maximum speed of the ball?
questions.explanation: Maximum tension provides the maximum centripetal force: T_max = m v_max² / r → v_max = √(T_max × r / m) = √(50.0 × 1.50 / 0.500) = √150 = 12.25 m/s ≈ 12.2 m/s.

questions.question: A roller coaster car of mass 500 kg is at the bottom of a vertical loop of radius 20.0 m, moving at 30.0 m/s. What is the normal force from the track? (Use g=10.0 m/s²)
questions.explanation: At the bottom, the net upward force is the centripetal force: N - mg = m v²/r → N = m(g + v²/r) = 500 kg × (10.0 + (30.0)²/20.0) = 500 × (10.0 + 45.0) = 27500 N = 2.75 × 10⁴ N.

questions.question: A 0.800 kg ball is swung in a vertical circle on a 0.600 m rope. The speed at the lowest point is 5.00 m/s. What is the tension in the rope? (Use g=9.80 m/s²)

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered force analysis in circular motion for both horizontal and vertical planes.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding. Carefully review the direction of forces at different points in vertical circles.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Drawing free-body diagrams. 2) At the top: T + mg = mv²/r. 3) At the bottom: T - mg = mv²/r.
scoreMessages.0: Start with: Circular motion requires a net centripetal force. In vertical circles, gravity affects tension. At the top: T + mg = mv²/r. At the bottom: T - mg = mv²/r.
